children.subject: If it's a popular class, you definitely should waitlist/enroll that class in phase one (even you haven't declared yet). If you are pretty sure it's won't be full till the last day to add, then that's totally fine.
If I will be declared CS by the end of this semester, should I waitlist upper division CS courses in phase 1 or wait till the adjustment period to enroll in?
can someone confirm whether we need to file Time Conflict application to enroll CS 188 and CS 170 or not according to the new policy?
Not in F18
Will 169 not be offered?

Same here, except I hope to be declared by the end of this semester. I signed up for CS170 and CS168 in Phase 1, so should I stick to being on the waitlist for these classes (I'm around 15th in both classes)?

OP, if you don't finish 70 in August, you will not be declared before the adjustment period. Therefore, declaring won't make a difference this time around. See: https://eecs.berkeley.edu/resources/undergrads/cs/degree-reqs/enrollment-policy

I just got this email: 
You remain on the wait list for the following class:



Term: 2018 Fall

Class: COMPSCI   170 

Section: 001



Reason: Available seats are reserved and you do not meet any requirements for the reserved seats.



You will remain on the wait list until a seat for which you qualify opens.

I will hopefully be declared by the end of summer as I am taking 70 over the summer. When I declare at the end of the summer, will I get in (I'm #9 on the waitlist) or should I find a backup plan?

waitlists process automatically 4 times a day
https://eecs.berkeley.edu/resources/undergrads/cs/degree-reqs/enrollment-policy
When will waitlists be processed? Phase 2 or Adjustment Period?
I think you have a good chance

If I have to wait until the adjustment period in order to get processed off the waitlist for CS170 but I am #8 on the waitlist (as I am currently undeclared), will I most likely get into the class or should I look for backup options?
yes, if the class fills and you are on the waitlist then you would not be guaranteed a spot..
How would students who are planning to declare Data Science enroll into courses like CS 170/188/161, etc.. if they don't get registration priority but still need to complete courses?

There are alternatives, they don't have to be CS courses. Is it crazy to think that CS/EECS students should get into EECS courses? DS students can take INDENG courses, INFO, and STAT courses to fulfill the same requirements, we have to take EECS courses. It would be incredibly frustrating if I didn't get into a spot in a class in my own major after phase 1 a popular class for a DS student who had 20+ other courses they could've used to fulfill the requirement.
That's a good point. I'd imagine it's very frustrating to not be able to enroll in classes that are primarily for your major.
I think this is an important conversation that will continue as the D.S. major is rolled out and grows

Thank you for your input and please keep us updated! I'd assume many students are very interested in pursuing D.S. but are unsure of how they should handle registration for the Fall semester and so on. Phase 1'ing high demand CS courses and staying on the waitlist is now even riskier for non-CS/EECS majors. It's from my understanding that the faculty working on the major want it to be as inclusive as possible since there's an incredible amount of interest and growth in the D.S. field, but as of right now it's already very difficult to enroll in high demand CS courses and it's only going to become even more difficult when the major is rolled out.

@Anon Although I understand your point that it's frustrating to not be able to get into courses of your own major, I think your tone is a little harsh. Many students want to get into CS 170 regardless of major, and it's good that students of non EECS/CS majors want to learn more about CS. I would be upset as well if I wanted to take a class outside of my major (which, in the case of DS, currently only has a very few classes that would give me priority enrollment) and found out that it could be more difficult to get into. Your major doesn't define which classes you want to take. In addition, the argument that DS students can take other classes to fulfill their requirements implies that they are only interested in taking classes to fill requirements - like CS/EECS students who have other classes that can fulfill their upper division CS course requirements, DS and non-CS/EECS major students likely want to take courses because they are interested, not just to fill requirements.

The issue should not be students from other majors taking CS/EECS "seats", it's an overall issue that the courses we have don't have the resources to take in all the people who take them.

Does not enforcing the 70% rule mean that non-CS/EECS majors who are waitlisted for classes in Phase 1 won't be guaranteed to get in if the class gets filled 100% by CS/EECS majors? Even if they have a very low waitlist spot?

The remaining seats will be released when GSI hiring is completed. That can happen any time - sometimes it isn't completed until just before classes begin.

Be aware that the reserve caps may prevent you from being enrolled even if the remainder of the seats are released. You can learn more about when you will be enrolled at:  https://eecs.berkeley.edu/resources/undergrads/cs/degree-reqs/enrollment-policy
Am i correct that if it does occur in the adjustment period or after that reserve caps do not apply anymore?
GSI hiring/releasing remainder of the seats is unrelated to when the reserve caps come down. The reserve caps will come down on 8/13 for this class.

Will CS160 be adding the 30% additional rest of the class starting in phase 2 or the adjustment period? I am currently a non-major who is number 2 on the waitlist and am wondering when it will be processed.
Look like you're enrolled

I am on the waitlist for CS 188 and currently my waitlist number is #13 (With 31 seats open in the class). I meet all requirements in order to be successfully enrolled in the class yet am still on the waitlist.

I recently noticed that a major chunk of the waitlist for this class has already been processed. 

I wanted to clarify that will more people from the waitlist be enrolled in the class? And/Or are these 31 seats reserved for something else?

history.content:
This is the master list of announcements for F18 upper div CS classes.  General enrollment information is at the end of this post.

Class-specific information UPDATED as of August 28, 2018:

  • CS 160 – Enrollment for this class has been closed and the wait list has been purged. No further enrollments will be accepted.
  • CS 161 – Enrollment for this class has expanded as of 8/27 and the wait list has been cleared.

Class-specific information UPDATED as of August 26, 2018:

  •  CS 188 – Maximum enrollment for this class has been increased to 850 seats and the wait list has been cleared.

Class-specific information UPDATED as of August 20, 2018:

  •          CS 160 – This class is fully enrolled. The instructor is currently considering if/how to expand the class further. For the first time this semester, this class has 3 lecture (enrollment) sections. The class will be simulcast between lecture rooms. Students need to enroll/waitlist for one of the lectures PLUS the 999 section. Due to this configuration, the wait list must be manually processed and changes will not happen as frequently as for other classes.

  •          CS 161 – This class is fully enrolled with a short wait list. No discussions at this time about expanding the class.

  •          CS 162 - This class is fully enrolled with a short wait list. No discussions at this time about expanding the class. Please note this is an early drop class!

  •          CS 164 - This class is fully enrolled with a short wait list. No discussions at this time about expanding the class.

  •          CS 168 – This class is fully enrolled. This class will NOT be expanding further and there will be NO webcasting.

  •          CS 170 – Class has been expanded.

  •          CS 176 – Class has been expanded.
  •          CS 186/286A – There are still seats available in this class. Lecture format is different from past semesters. Lectures will be facilitated by GSIs with videos of Professor incorporated. No CS 286A is offered in F18.
  •          CS 188 – This class is fully enrolled. No discussions at this time about expanding the class.
  •          CS 189/289A – This class was over-enrolled. The class will NOT be webcast. Further enrollment is closed as is the wait list. If you are not on the wait list for this class, you will not be able to put yourself on the wait list.
  •          CS 194-026 – This class is fully enrolled. No discussions at this time about expanding the class.
  •          CS 194-031 – This class is fully enrolled with a short wait list. No discussions at this time about expanding the class.
  •          CS 198 (DeCals) – at this point all but one class is set to require instructor consent. If you want to enroll into any of these classes, you should contact the instructor for a permission code.

 

 

The remainder of this post will contain general enrollment information that will be updated as more information becomes available.

  1. To see who can enroll into CS upper div classes and when, read: https://eecs.berkeley.edu/resources/undergrads/cs/degree-reqs/enrollment-policy#upper 

  2. Time Conflicts - NEW for F18: The enrollment system WILL ALLOW time conflicts between CompSci classes and other classes. However, even though CalCentral will allow enrollment into both classes, it is still the student’s responsibility to plan their schedule carefully. Departments and faculty are NOT required or expected to accommodate students’ schedule conflicts, and the Instructor of Record may decline to enroll or Instructor Drop a student from a class if they cannot be present for all schedule activities, including midterms and finals.

    Best practice is to speak to the instructors before enrolling in time conflicted classes.

  3. Waitlist Processing:

  • We will NOT purge the waitlist of non-CS/EECS majors at the end of phase 1 this semester.

  • Wait lists are automatically processed in numerical order based on the waitlist position. A student’s major is NOT taken into consideration when the wait list is processed.

  • If enrolling the student into the class will put them over the maximum number of units, the system will also skip the student when processing the wait list. Units for wait listed classes count towards the upper unit limit: 13.5 phase 1, 17.5 phase 2, and 20 units over all.

  • Waitlisted students who have time conflicts will no longer be held on the waitlist and will now be processed in sequential order like any other student. (As in the past, not meeting a reserve cap or exceeding the unit limit will still prevent students from being enrolled from the wait list.)

    Students on the waitlist for a class are NOT guaranteed to get into the class and should make a reasonable back-up plan.

 

  1. The 70% rule  - NEW for F18: All upper division classes (EXCEPT for CS 160/260A) will now allow full enrollment beginning April 16, 2018. In F18, we are not enforcing the 70% rule as we have in past semesters with one exception. (see notes for CS 160/260A below to learn about the 70% rule)

 

  1. 999 sections will be used for nearly all upper div classes. These are faux sections that allow students to enroll in the lecture and the 999 section(s) only via Cal Central. 

    Since students no longer drop/re-enroll when they want to switch sections, they will no longer risk being bumped to the end of the waitlist when they need to make a change. Additionally, the 999 section has no scheduled day or time which reduces the number of time conflicts that must be processed online. It DOES mean that students need to be patient and wait until class starts to know which section they will actually attend.

    Students can still see the actual section days/times via classes.berkeley.edu

    Assignments to actual sections will be handled outside of Cal Central by faculty either:

    *  During first lecture
    *  Via communication from instructor to use alternate form (e.g. Google form)
    *  Via course home page

history.subject: UPDATED F18: Getting in to Upper Div COMPSCI Classes

history.content:
This is the master list of announcements for F18 upper div CS classes.  Class-specific information is at the end of this post.

 

  1. To see who can enroll into CS upper div classes and when, read: https://eecs.berkeley.edu/resources/undergrads/cs/degree-reqs/enrollment-policy#upper 

  2. Time Conflicts - NEW for F18: The enrollment system WILL ALLOW time conflicts between CompSci classes and other classes. However, even though CalCentral will allow enrollment into both classes, it is still the student’s responsibility to plan their schedule carefully. Departments and faculty are NOT required or expected to accommodate students’ schedule conflicts, and the Instructor of Record may decline to enroll or Instructor Drop a student from a class if they cannot be present for all schedule activities, including midterms and finals.

    Best practice is to speak to the instructors before enrolling in time conflicted classes.

  3. Waitlist Processing:

  • We will NOT purge the waitlist of non-CS/EECS majors at the end of phase 1 this semester.

  • Wait lists are automatically processed in numerical order based on the waitlist position. A student’s major is NOT taken into consideration when the wait list is processed.

  • If enrolling the student into the class will put them over the maximum number of units, the system will also skip the student when processing the wait list. Units for wait listed classes count towards the upper unit limit: 13.5 phase 1, 17.5 phase 2, and 20 units over all.

  • Waitlisted students who have time conflicts will no longer be held on the waitlist and will now be processed in sequential order like any other student. (As in the past, not meeting a reserve cap or exceeding the unit limit will still prevent students from being enrolled from the wait list.)

    Students on the waitlist for a class are NOT guaranteed to get into the class and should make a reasonable back-up plan.

 

  1. The 70% rule  - NEW for F18: All upper division classes (EXCEPT for CS 160/260A) will now allow full enrollment beginning April 16, 2018. In F18, we are not enforcing the 70% rule as we have in past semesters with one exception. (see notes for CS 160/260A below to learn about the 70% rule)

 

  1. 999 sections will be used for nearly all upper div classes. These are faux sections that allow students to enroll in the lecture and the 999 section(s) only via Cal Central. 

    Since students no longer drop/re-enroll when they want to switch sections, they will no longer risk being bumped to the end of the waitlist when they need to make a change. Additionally, the 999 section has no scheduled day or time which reduces the number of time conflicts that must be processed online. It DOES mean that students need to be patient and wait until class starts to know which section they will actually attend.

    Students can still see the actual section days/times via classes.berkeley.edu

    Assignments to actual sections will be handled outside of Cal Central by faculty either:

    *  During first lecture
    *  Via communication from instructor to use alternate form (e.g. Google form)
    *  Via course home page

 

The remainder of this post will contain class-specific information that will be updated as more information becomes available.

 

  • CS C100 (aka DATA c100/STAT c100) - enrollments are being coordinated by STAT department and will all be funneled through the STAT section.  Students should enroll via STAT C100.
  • CS 160/260A – This is the only class using the 70% rule for F18. That means that 30% of the seats will be held back as permission only until GSI/TA hiring is completed. Waitlisted students, please do NOT email asking for a permission code. Instead, be patient and we will release additional seats as soon as possible at which time the wait list will AUTOMATICALLY process and fill those seats in the order in which people are listed on the wait list for the class.

    In F18, the lecture for CS 160 will be held in 3 rooms simultaneously (simulcast). I have no further information about the room from which the instructor will lecture. Undergrad students need to choose which lecture section they want to attend along with the 999 discussion section.

    Grad students enrolling in CS 260A are restricted to one lecture section and the 999 discussion section.

  • CS 162 is an Early Drop Deadline class. This means that students who are enrolled and want to drop have to do by no later than end of week 2 (August 31 for F18) or they’ll need to get a Dean’s permission to override.  This is done so teams aren’t left in the lurch if one of their members abandons the class late.

 

  •   CS 198 - DeCal classes are offered at the facilitator’s discretion and probably won’t appear on the class schedule until later in Phase 2. Please check classes.berkeley.edu to see which classes are being offered - the list will be updated as more information becomes available.

#pin
history.subject: F18: Getting in to Upper Div COMPSCI Classes

history.content:
This is the master list of announcements for F18 upper div CS classes.  Class-specific information is at the end of this post.

 

  1. To see who can enroll into CS upper div classes and when, read: https://eecs.berkeley.edu/resources/undergrads/cs/degree-reqs/enrollment-policy#upper 

  2. Time Conflicts - NEW for F18: The enrollment system WILL ALLOW time conflicts between CompSci classes and other classes. However, even though CalCentral will allow enrollment into both classes, it is still the student’s responsibility to plan their schedule carefully. Departments and faculty are NOT required or expected to accommodate students’ schedule conflicts, and the Instructor of Record may decline to enroll or Instructor Drop a student from a class if they cannot be present for all schedule activities, including midterms and finals.

    Best practice is to speak to the instructors before enrolling in time conflicted classes.

  3. Waitlist Processing:

  • We will NOT purge the waitlist of non-CS/EECS majors at the end of phase 1 this semester.

  • Wait lists are automatically processed in numerical order based on the waitlist position. A student’s major is NOT taken into consideration when the wait list is processed.

  • If enrolling the student into the class will put them over the maximum number of units, the system will also skip the student when processing the wait list. Units for wait listed classes count towards the upper unit limit: 13.5 phase 1, 17.5 phase 2, and 20 units over all.

  • Waitlisted students who have time conflicts will no longer be held on the waitlist and will now be processed in sequential order like any other student. (As in the past, not meeting a reserve cap or exceeding the unit limit will still prevent students from being enrolled from the wait list.)

    Students on the waitlist for a class are NOT guaranteed to get into the class and should make a reasonable back-up plan.

 

  1. The 70% rule  - NEW for F18: All upper division classes (EXCEPT for CS 160/260A) will now allow full enrollment beginning April 16, 2018. In F18, we are not enforcing the 70% rule as we have in past semesters with one exception. (see notes for CS 160/260A below to learn about the 70% rule)

 

  1. 999 sections will be used for nearly all upper div classes. These are faux sections that allow students to enroll in the lecture and the 999 section(s) only via Cal Central. 

    Since students no longer drop/re-enroll when they want to switch sections, they will no longer risk being bumped to the end of the waitlist when they need to make a change. Additionally, the 999 section has no scheduled day or time which reduces the number of time conflicts that must be processed online. It DOES mean that students need to be patient and wait until class starts to know which section they will actually attend.

    Students can still see the actual section days/times via classes.berkeley.edu

    Assignments to actual sections will be handled outside of Cal Central by faculty either:

    *  During first lecture
    *  Via communication from instructor to use alternate form (e.g. Google form)
    *  Via course home page

 

The remainder of this post will contain class-specific information that will be updated as more information becomes available.

 

  • CS C100 (aka DATA c100/STAT c100) - enrollments are being coordinated by STAT department and will all be funneled through the STAT section.  Students should enroll via STAT C100.

  • CS 160/260A – This is the only class using the 70% rule for F18. That means that 30% of the seats will be held back as permission only until GSI/TA hiring is completed. Waitlisted students, please do NOT email asking for a permission code. Instead, be patient and we will release additional seats as soon as possible at which time the wait list will AUTOMATICALLY process and fill those seats in the order in which people are listed on the wait list for the class.

    In F18, the lecture for CS 160 will be held in 3 rooms simultaneously (simulcast). I have no further information about the room from which the instructor will lecture. Undergrad students need to choose which lecture section they want to attend along with the 999 discussion section.

    Grad students enrolling in CS 260A are restricted to one lecture section and the 999 discussion section.

  • CS 162 is an Early Drop Deadline class. This means that students who are enrolled and want to drop have to do by no later than end of week 2 (August 31 for F18) or they’ll need to get a Dean’s permission to override.  This is done so teams aren’t left in the lurch if one of their members abandons the class late.

 

  •   CS 198 - DeCal classes are offered at the facilitator’s discretion and probably won’t appear on the class schedule until later in Phase 2. Please check classes.berkeley.edu to see which classes are being offered - the list will be updated as more information becomes available.
